reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s optimism about moral trade being facilitated by “iron-clad contracts” enabled by superintelligence. This is relevant to section 3’s pathway (trade/compromise), but it is not fully central to the overall position (which is broader: pessimism about WAM-convergence, mixed/conditional optimism about trade under various conditions, plus many other blockers like threats and power concentration). The critique has some force because the essay does not spell out concrete verification/enforcement mechanisms, so it weakens the credibility of that enabling assumption. However, it overstates the dependency (trade needn’t ‘collapse’ entirely without perfect trustless protocols) and demands an arguably too-strong standard (mathematical guarantees against any superintelligent adversary), so it doesn’t robustly refute the trade argument. It is mostly clear and focused, with minor rhetorical fluff.
title: Iron-clad contracts lack formal verification mechanisms against superintelligent defection
